slides.text:
Let's begin this chapter with a story. There are many versions of it floating around, but it generally goes like this... 

 One day you were out for a morning walk. What a beautiful sunny day! 

  You meditate on what to eat for breakfast, what to do in the afternoon, and what is the meaning of your life... 

 But as you turn a corner, and out of nowhere, whoa! A scene of bizarre **atrocity** unfolded right in front of you...

slides.dialogueText:
In front of you is a railway track with 2 forking pathways.  

 Some insane fanatic has tied 5 people on one track, and 1 person on the other. 

 A trolley is approaching in high speed. It is going too fast to stop.
slides.reference: Image sourced from Bizarro, S. (2020, June 6). *The Trolley Problem — Origins*. Medium. https://sarabizarro.medium.com/the-trolley-problem-73e22048d88e

slides.dialogueText:
In a whirlwind of shock, dread, panic, disbelief, paralysis, followed by a state of chaotic *Zen* with a Mulholland-Drive-esque dreamy lucidity, you find that somehow a lever has been *shoved* into your hands. 

 On the lever, it says: "pull lever to switch track"
slides.reference: MedievalFurnace (2024), *Oh no! The trolley problem is in a first person perspective! [Online Forum Post]*. Reddit. https://www.reddit.com/r/trolleyproblem/comments/1fwxd8j/oh_no_the_trolley_problem_is_in_a_first_person/

slides.dialogueText:
The trolley is headed towards the track with 5 people. If you pull the lever, you divert the trolley to the track with 1 person. 

 If you do nothing, 5 will die. If you change the tracks, 1 person who otherwise would've survived this atrocity will die. 

 Time is ticking. What should you do?
slides.reference: Image sourced from Bizarro, S. (2020, June 6). *The Trolley Problem — Origins*. Medium. https://sarabizarro.medium.com/the-trolley-problem-73e22048d88e

chats.text: OH MY GOD WHAT DO I DO???
WHAT DO I DO WHAT DO I DO ITS COMING OMFG!!!
Do it.
WHAT?
Pull the lever. Five deaths is worse than one.
Great! Let's maximise the pleasure of Elon Musk. Cuz why not?
...for the greatest number of people. Do it for EVERYONE.
Are you saying that Elon's pleasures and pains are less worthy than the pleasures and pains of a homeless drug addict?
No but there are millions of poor and only one Elon Musk.
It's just not fair to take from those who worked hard and give to those who are incompetent.
With $100 you could feed someone who is starving and can save a life. But $100 for a billionaire means nothing.
So?
So? Take $100 from a billionaire causes virtually no pain. But giving $100 to a starving homeless man creates immense benefit. Greatest good for the greatest number, measured in pleasure and pain.
But isn't this just punishing those who are successful? It's the tall poppy syndrome, old man.
Don't flip your wig kid. It has nothing to do with punishment or reward. Utilitarianism looks at results and results only. Nothing else matters.
You're just giving freebies to those who don't deserve it.
Greatest good for the greatest number. Results only, nothing else matters. Try again.
Nope, not convinced. Not doing it.
Then you are acting unethically.
Wtf why?
Because utilitarianism is precisely about what is ethical. It allows you to judge whether an action is ethical.
And you are moral and ethical only if you try to achieve the greatest good for the greatest number.
No way. You can't justify why we should aim for the greatest good for the greatest number, and why not doing so makes me unethical.
Then go read my book. It's only about 300 pages. It's required reading for this course by the way. Also your essay is due tomorrow morning kid. Now get back to work.

slides.reference: Driver, J. (2009, March 27). *The History of Utilitarianism*. Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; Stanford University.

slides.text:
It is better to be a human being dissatisfied than a pig satisfied; better to be Socrates dissatisfied than a fool satisfied. 

 And if the fool, or the pig, are of a different opinion, it is because they only know their own side of the question.
slides.reference: Mill, J. S. (1863). *Utilitarianism* (p. 14). Parker, Son, and Bourn. Image from *John Stuart Mill - Econlib*. (2018). Econlib.
